channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Orders Brief Unilateral Cease-Fire; Ukraine Calls It ‘Hypocrisy’
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin told Russian forces to observe a 36-hour Christmas truce, but Ukraine dismissed it as hypocrisy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Finds Sexual Crimes in Regions Russia Occupied
item.description: Investigators have uncovered widespread evidence of abuse by Moscow’s forces, including rape and forced nudity. Kremlin officials have repeatedly denied accusations of rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha, a 26-year-old Ukrainian, has faced sexual violence by Russian soldiers when she was detained in Kherson.

item.title: Church Lays Benedict to Rest, if Not Its Divisions
item.description: An extraordinary period for the modern church ended with Francis presiding over the funeral of his retired predecessor. Some conservatives found the ceremony too modest for their standard-bearer.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis presiding over the funeral for Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI in St. Peter’s Square on Thursday.

item.title: How a Nuclear Dump in Taiwan Created a Generation of Activists
item.description: For members of a Taiwanese tribe, a waste site on their island serves as a painful reminder of the government’s broken promises, and a symbol of their long struggle for greater autonomy.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: The nuclear waste dump site on the Taiwanese island of Lanyu. The government in the 1970s built the site to store thousands of barrels of low-level radioactive waste produced by nuclear power plants on the main island.

item.title: El Chapo’s Son Is Captured by Mexican Authorities for 2nd Time
item.description: The arrest of Ovidio Guzmán López was a victory for the Mexican government. He had been briefly detained in 2019, but was released after cartel gunmen overpowered law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Steve Fisher
item.media:description: A vehicle burns following clashes between federal forces and armed groups in Culiacan, Mexico, on Thursday.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Memoir Alleges Physical Attack by William, According to Report
item.description: “He knocked me to the floor,” Harry recounts of the alleged assault by Prince William, according to The Guardian, which said it had obtained a copy of Harry’s coming book.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The princes and their wives in Windsor, England, in September. Prince Harry, second from left, said that he had been attacked by his brother, William, right, during a furious argument over Harry’s marriage to Meghan Markle, left.

item.title: Twin Car Explosions Kill More than 20 in Somalia
item.description: A terrorist group, Al Shabab, claimed responsibility for the attacks, which came as the militants lose control of towns and villages to a government offensive.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security forces in Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, ahead of a presidential election last year.

item.title: Sunak Makes Sweeping Pledges to Britons, Promising Path to Prosperity
item.description: His promises represented an effort to regain momentum at a time of steep challenges for Britain, but some pressing problems, like the National Health Service, defy easy solutions.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaking in London on Wednesday.

item.title: The Funeral for Pope Benedict XVI, in Photos
item.description: Benedict XVI was laid to rest in a ceremony that marked the end of an unusual arrangement during which he lived on the Vatican grounds after having resigned in 2013.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coffin of Pope Benedict XVI was carried out of St Peter’s Basilica on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Claims Heavy Russian Losses in Waves of Missile Strikes
item.description: Kyiv says its forces have killed or wounded hundreds of Russian soldiers in a series of pinpoint attacks. Russia has confirmed only one of three waves of strikes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: A Ukrainian High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, or HIMARS, firing on Russian positions in the Kherson region in November.

item.title: Russian Troops’ Use of Cellphones Is a Persistent, Lethal Danger
item.description: Ukrainian artillery targets Russian soldiers by pinpointing their phone signals. Despite the deadly results, Russian troops keep defying a ban on cellphone use near the front.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:description: A Russian soldier taking a photo on his mobile phone at the Mariupol theater in April.

item.title: The ‘Golden Gays’ Return to the Stage in the Philippines
item.description: They formed a community meant to support and shelter gay people who had been cast aside by society. Decades later, they are still living together, hosting pageants to help make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Reyes Morales
item.media:description: Members of the Golden Gays preparing for a show in Manila. The money they raise through their performances is used to sustain a home and basic needs as they age.

item.title: Actress Detained for Supporting Iranian Protests Is Released on Bail
item.description: Taraneh Alidoosti, one of the most high-profile targets in Iran’s campaign against celebrities who have expressed solidarity with the demonstrators, was arrested on Dec. 18.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Iranian actress Taraneh Alidoosti after being released Wednesday from prison on bail.

item.title: E.U. Urges Nations to Require Negative Covid Tests for Travelers From China
item.description: In a diplomatically fraught move, the bloc advised its 27 members to put restrictions in place as Chinese tourists prepare to return to global destinations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A Covid screening site for passengers from China at Leonardo da Vinci international airport in Rome on Dec. 29.

item.title: Putin Calls a 36-Hour Cease-Fire, but Ukraine and U.S. Are Skeptical
item.description: The cease-fire would coincide with the Eastern Orthodox Christmas on Saturday, but Kremlin adversaries and some analysts call it a ploy for military and political advantage.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Fighters from Ukraine’s Karpatska Sich Battalion in a church on Dec. 25 that was destroyed by shelling and reportedly looted by Russian forces during their occupation, in the Lyman district in the Donetsk region.

item.title: Kenneth Rowe, Who Defected From North Korea With His Jet, Dies at 90
item.description: Two months after the Korean War armistice, he handed America an intelligence bonanza with his headline-making flight in a Soviet-made MIG.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Lt. No Kum-Sok of the North Korean Air Force in 1953, the year he defected. He changed his name to Kenneth Rowe and became an American citizen.

item.title: U.S. Officials Repatriate a Looted Relic to the Palestinian Authority
item.description: As the object, a carved spoon, was handed back at a ceremony in Bethlehem, officials said it was the first time the United States had repatriated an antiquity to the Palestinian government.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office.
item.media:description: A cosmetic spoon carved from ivory, which officials said had been looted, was returned to the Palestinian Authority.

item.title: For the State Department, Now It’s Türkiye, Not Turkey
item.description: The department will use the Turkish-language spelling in “most formal, diplomatic, and bilateral contexts” after a request from the country’s embassy, a spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Murat Kula/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has publicly opposed the use of the Anglicized spelling for his country and has pushed for the rest of the world to use its Turkish-language name.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Proposes a Short Cease-Fire
item.description: Also, Kevin McCarthy loses yet another bid to become House speaker, and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged church in a village in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: Some Find Fault With Francis’ Homily for Benedict
item.description: The former pope’s supporters, who include conservatives, said Francis’ approach seemed paltry in comparison to Benedict’s homily at the funeral of Pope John Paul II.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis’ homily for his predecessor, Benedict XVI, has drawn some criticism from the church’s conservative wing.

item.title: Biden Announces Major Crackdown on Illegal Border Crossings
item.description: President Biden, who is under pressure to confront a surge in migration at the border, said he would visit El Paso on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Mr. Biden described the new approach as one intended to expand opportunities for migrants.

item.title: In a phone call with Putin, Turkey’s president calls for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neighbors helping to clear belongings on Sunday from a house in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was damaged by a Russian strike.

item.title: Russia Pardons Some Prisoners Who Fought in Ukraine, Reports Say
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner paramilitary group, is seen in a video congratulating men for completing their military contracts.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: A pro-military poster near the Wagner Group’s headquarters in St. Petersburg, Russia, in November.

item.title: Most of Bakhmut Has Been Destroyed in Ukraine War, Official Says
item.description: Russia has continued to press an offensive aimed at capturing the eastern city, after suffering a string of setbacks elsewhere in Ukraine in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Walking past a destroyed building in Bakhmut last month.

item.title: Violence in the N.F.L.
item.description: In professional football, danger is at the root of any given play.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: Buffalo Bills fans at a vigil for Damar Hamlin at Highmark Stadium in Orchard Park, New York.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Homily for Benedict Calls Him a ‘Faithful Friend’ of Jesus
item.description: Pope Francis’ short speech honored the former pontiff, whose life’s work was meditating on the life of Jesus, and who faced many challenges before retiring in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivering the homily at the funeral on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The Russian authorities have laid the blame for a deadly Ukrainian strike on their soldiers themselves.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian soldier taking a photo on his mobile phone at the Mariupol theater in April.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Blames its Dead Soldiers
item.description: Also, Kim Jong-un presents a possible successor.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Workers in Makiivka, Ukraine, removing debris on Tuesday from the destroyed building that Russian soldiers had been using as a barracks.

item.title: France Promises Ukraine Armored Vehicles, U.S. Weighs Doing the Same
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron pledged to provide AMX-10 RC armored vehicles, though Mr. Macron’s office did not specify how many of the vehicles would be delivered or when.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: France plans to send AMX-10 RC armored vehicles to Ukraine.

item.title: Some European Nations See Warmest Start to the Year Ever Measured
item.description: Countries across the continent saw the warmest start to the year ever measured. The weather has forced ski resorts to close trails, with sparser than usual snow cover.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Dietmar Stiplovsek/APA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Ahead of Pope Benedict’s Funeral, Faithful Gather in the Vatican
item.description: About 200,000 came to see the pope emeritus, who died on Saturday at age 95, as he lay in state for three days ahead of his funeral on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of the pope emeritus, Benedict XVI, inside St. Peter’s Basilica on Wednesday.

item.title: When Darkness Falls, Three Friends Find Ancient Art
item.description: Some Norwegian hobbyists are having a great time uncovering hundreds of Bronze Age carvings. Their discoveries have lent weight to theories about what the mysterious images mean.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Lars Ole Klavestad, Magnus Tangen and Tormod Fjeld hunting for Bronze Age rock carvings in the Ostfold region of southeastern Norway last month.

item.title: A House Divided
item.description: House Republicans are struggling with a test of governing.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy yesterday.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Tokyo
item.description: Hiromi Kawakami, one of Japan’s most popular contemporary novelists, travels with books that help her immerse herself in her destination. Here, she suggests reading for those coming to her hometown, Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: Hiromi Kawakami and translated by Allison Markin Powell
item.category: The Narrow Road to the Deep North (Book)

item.title: ​Is Kim Jong-un’s ‘Most Beloved Daughter’ North Korea’s Next Leader?
item.description: Her appearances in state media, most recently in undated photos released on New Year’s Day, have triggered growing speculation about succession plans in the country.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed Kim Jong-un and his daughter after a test missile launch in November.

item.title: Russia Blames Soldiers’ Cellphone Use For Deadly Makiivka Strike
item.description: The Defense Ministry said the use of phones helped Ukraine home in on the troops’ location, while influential military bloggers said that explanation ignored commanders’ mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Workers in Makiivka, Ukraine, removing debris on Tuesday from the destroyed building that Russian soldiers had been using as a barracks.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukraine has begun using searchlights to spot drones. Kyiv on Sunday.

item.title: Benedict Leaves a Conflicted Legacy on Clerical Sexual Abuse
item.description: Joseph Ratzinger was accused of mishandling cases when he was bishop of Munich, but as pope he was credited with forcing the Catholic Church to face a scourge long ignored.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Munich and Freising in Germany. Supporters of Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI note that he forced the Roman Catholic Church to make it easier to get rid of abusers. Others say he did not go far enough.

item.title: Ukraine Keeps Downing Russian Drones, but Price Tag Is High
item.description: When costly missiles take out cheap drones, the real winner over time may be the country that spends less.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A Russian drone was spotted over Kyiv during an attack in October.

item.title: Filippo Bernardini, Accused of Stealing Book Manuscripts, Expected to Plead Guilty
item.description: Filippo Bernardini was arrested by the F.B.I. last year. He is expected to enter his plea on Friday, ending a yearslong saga that captivated the industry.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Richard Baker/In Pictures via Getty Images
item.media:description: A London bookstore. Upon arresting Bernardini, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said he had organized a scheme to gain access to hundreds of unpublished manuscripts.

item.title: Putin Prepares Russians for Long Fight Ahead
item.description: The Russian leader has dropped the pretense that life goes on as normal despite the war, evident in the Kremlin’s quick acknowledgment of mass casualties inflicted by Ukraine last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A family in Moscow watching President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia address the nation for the New Year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Chaos in the U.S. House Speaker Race
item.description: Also, China threatens countermeasures against travel restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Prince Harry Says He Wants His Family Back in ITV, ’60 Minutes’ Interviews
item.description: With Prince Harry’s new book, “Spare,” set to be released next week, Britain is gearing up for the release of revealing new interviews with the estranged royal.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Prince William in September at the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in London.

item.title: Activist Who Removed Banksy Mural in Ukraine Could Face Prison, Police Say
item.description: The mural, showing a woman in a bathrobe wearing a gas mask and holding a fire extinguisher, was one of seven artworks painted by Banksy on war-ravaged buildings in and around Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: A mural by the British street artist Banksy was removed by a group of activists from the wall of a destroyed building in the Kyiv suburb of Hostomel in December.

item.title: Germany’s Inflation Rate Hit a High in 2022
item.description: The pace of consumer price increases began easing late in the year, but the country’s annual rate of inflation set a new, post-Cold War record.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: In a Hospital Ward, the Wounds of Tunisia’s Failed Democracy Don’t Heal
item.description: Tunisia’s road to democracy began with a self-immolation, and such cases have filled hospital burn wards ever since, as elected leaders failed to deliver on a promise of prosperity.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Zied Ben Romdhane for The New York Times

item.title: France’s César Film Awards Bar Nominees Investigated on Sexual Violence Charges
item.description: The César Academy’s decision is its latest effort to improve its image after years marked by abuse scandals.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Actors and crew members of “Les Amandiers” (“Forever Young”) in Cannes, France, in May. Sofiane Bennacer, center right, who stars in the film, is under police investigation on rape charges.

item.title: China Denounces Covid Testing Rules Imposed on Its Travelers
item.description: A government spokeswoman said Beijing would consider reciprocal measures against countries that have sought to limit travelers arriving from China.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Health workers guided travelers from China arriving in South Korea to a Covid testing center at Incheon International Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Deadly strike on Russians in Ukraine exposes Moscow’s military failings.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Workers removed debris from a destroyed building in Makiivka on Tuesday, where at least 63 Russian soldiers were killed in an attack by the Ukrainian military on New Year’s Day.

item.title: Philippines: Christmas Floods Kill 51 and Strand Thousands
item.description: Heavy rains on Christmas Day killed dozens of people and left thousands displaced. For a deeply Catholic nation, the timing heightened the sense of tragedy.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP), via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A rescue worker helping a resident cross a flooded street on Christmas in Gingoog City, the Philippines.

item.title: Hard-Line Israeli Minister Visits Volatile Jerusalem Holy Site
item.description: Itamar Ben-Gvir, the ultranationalist national security minister, toured the site just days after taking office, drawing a furious reaction from Palestinian leaders.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli security personnel near visitors at the Dome of the Rock in the compound in Jerusalem’s Old City known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A major strike on Russian troops.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents after collecting humanitarian aid in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
item.description: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American military personnel in February at Mihail Kogalniceanu air base in Romania. The base has long been used to train NATO forces.

item.title: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
item.description: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Benedict’s Death Leaves Catholic Conservatives Bereft
item.description: Even after his resignation as pope, traditionalists invoked Benedict’s name and sought to draw him into internecine ideological wars. Now he is gone.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI celebrating Mass in Washington in 2008.

item.title: HIMARS, a US-Made Rocket System, Has Helped Give Ukraine Momentum
item.description: Washington delivered the first batch of truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers, known as HIMARS,
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military firing a rocket from a HIMARS near the frontline in the Kherson region in Ukraine.

item.title: A Balkan Leader Gets the Hollywood Treatment, Starring Kevin Spacey
item.description: A director cast the beleaguered actor as Franjo Tudjman, the late Croatian leader, whom some call a patriot and others revile as an ethnonationalist zealot.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Once Upon a Time in Croatia (Movie)
item.media:description: Croatia’s first president, Franjo Tudjman, was described by one historian as “one of the more egregiously unattractive” leaders to emerge in the breakup of Yugoslavia.

item.title: Dubai Suspends Alcohol Tax as Regional Competition Heats Up
item.description: Lower-cost liquor could help the emirate keep its edge over neighbors like Saudi Arabia and Qatar as the Middle East’s hub for leisure and business.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A waterfront restaurant in Dubai in 2020. Alcohol is now taxed at 30 percent in the emirate, and individuals need to buy a license to purchase it.

item.title: U.K. Rail Strike May Scuttle Post-Holiday Plans to Return to Work
item.description: Public sympathy for striking nurses and other health workers is particularly strong, posing a challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has promised to confront trade unions.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Polling suggests some fall in sympathy for British railroad workers, but also that other strikes, particularly in the health system, have widespread backing.

item.title: Pope Benedict Lies In State, Drawing Thousands of Mourners
item.description: The pope emeritus is lying in state in St. Peter’s Basilica, where some 65,000 mourners, including Roman Catholic faithful and tourists, had paid last respects by Monday evening.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, lying in state in St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City on Monday.

item.title: The Question of Life Itself
item.description: How people regard the start of life is complicated, polarizing and worthy of exploration.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Bethany Mollenkof for The New York Times
item.media:description: A baby being held.
